item.title: ¿Por qué el enrojecimiento facial empeora con el paso del tiempo?
item.description: Los científicos no están del todo seguros de qué causa el enrojecimiento facial ni de por qué se intensifica con la edad, pero tienen algunas teorías.
item.dc:creator: Erica Sweeney

media:content.media:credit: Eric Helgas para The New York Times

item.title: Word of the Day: commensurate
item.description: This word has appeared in 117 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Late Night Thanks the White House for a ‘Doozy of an Interview’
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel was grateful that Susie Wiles, the president’s “future former chief of staff,” spilled the beans on her boss in a Vanity Fair article.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Grief Mixes With Anger at Funeral of Rabbi Killed in Bondi Beach Attack
item.description: The funeral for Rabbi Eli Schlanger on Wednesday was the first held for one of the 15 people killed in a mass shooting at a Jewish celebration in Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

media:content.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mourners arriving at the Chabad of Bondi on Wednesday for the funeral of Eli Schlanger, in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: First Funeral Held For Victim of Bondi Beach Shooting
item.description: People mourned the death of Rabbi Eli Schlanger during the first funeral for those killed in the Bondi Beach shooting. He was a key organizer of the Jewish event that was tarnished by a mass shooting.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mourners arriving at the Chabad of Bondi on Wednesday for the funeral of Eli Schlanger, in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: La consigna anticorrupción que ayudó a derrocar al gobierno en Bulgaria
item.description: ​​Aunque el país ha vivido manifestaciones populares desde la caída del comunismo, esta vez los búlgaros dijeron que la indignación, ocasionada por la corrupción y el aumento de impuestos, se había desbordado.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall

media:content.media:credit: Valentina Petrova/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Manifestantes en Sofía, Bulgaria, este mes. El detonante de las manifestaciones fue un presupuesto que subía los impuestos y aumentaba los salarios de los miembros del aparato de seguridad del Estado.

item.title: Chile Is Swerving to the Right — and Into the Past
item.description: Chile’s new leader wants to rewrite its past and recast its future.
item.dc:creator: Ariel Dorfman
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:credit: Eitan Abramovich/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Suspect in Bondi Beach Killings Is Charged With Murder and Terrorism
item.description: The Australian authorities said the 24-year-old man, who had been shot by the police, woke from a coma on Tuesday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim

media:content.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The coffin of Rabbi Eli Schlanger arriving at the Chabad of Bondi for his funeral in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday.

item.title: On Bali, the Holiday Vibe Masks Memories of a Massacre
item.description: Sixty years ago, half a million Indonesians were killed in anti-Communist purges. On Bali, resorts and clubs were built atop mass graves.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:description: A graveyard on the Indonesian island of Bali where some of the victims of anti-Communist killings in the 1960s are believed to have been buried.

item.title: Does China Have a Robot Bubble?
item.description: The Chinese government is betting that robots will drive economic growth. But the bots can’t really do much yet.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu

media:content.media:credit: Jade Gao/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A new Chinese humanoid robot appeared so lifelike that workers cut its leg open during a demonstration last month.

item.title: Europa y EE. UU. dicen avanzar en un plan para blindar a Ucrania
item.description: Aunque los funcionarios europeos dijeron que estaban trabajando bien con los negociadores estadounidenses, a algunos les preocupa que el trabajo diplomático sea irrelevante si no se resuelven las disputas fundamentales entre Rusia y Ucrania.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze

media:content.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Soldados ucranianos durante un ejercicio de tiro real en un campo de entrenamiento militar en la región de Dnipró, este mes.

item.title: On British Roads, Chinese Cars Are Racing Ahead
item.description: BYD, Chery and other Chinese automakers are winning over drivers in Britain, where tariffs are low and buyers are open to new brands.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson

media:content.media:credit: Owen Richards for The New York Times

item.title: Norman Podhoretz, Influential Editor and Neoconservative Force, Dies at 95
item.description: A New York intellectual and onetime liberal stalwart, his Commentary magazine became his platform as his political and social view turned sharply rightward.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger

media:content.media:credit: Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Norman Podhoretz in 1971.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 17, 2025
item.description: Gary Larson and Doug Peterson have outmaneuvered us.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Why Nick Reiner Could Face the Death Penalty
item.description: The two first-degree murder counts include a special circumstance, which increases the maximum punishment if he is convicted.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla

media:content.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Nathan J. Hochman, the Los Angeles County district attorney, at a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: Prosecutors Charge Nick Reiner With Murdering His Parents
item.description: Los Angeles prosecutors charged Nick Reiner with two counts of first-degree murder in the deaths of his parents, the director Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Nathan J. Hochman, the Los Angeles County district attorney, discussed the Nick Reiner case at a news conference on Tuesday. It wasn’t clear when Reiner would enter his plea.

item.title: New Details Emerge About How Rob and Michele Reiner Were Found
item.description: A person close to the family provided a detailed account of what occurred in the Reiner house after a massage therapist received no response at the gate.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler and Matt Stevens

media:content.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Romy Reiner discovered the body of her father, Rob Reiner, inside the family’s mansion on Sunday.

item.title: Stephen King: Por qué abracé a Rob Reiner tras ver ‘Stand by Me’
item.description: En manos de Rob, mi novela más autobiográfica sonó auténtica.
item.dc:creator: Stephen King

media:content.media:credit: Foto ilustración de The New York Times

item.title: Trump Orders Blockade of Some Oil Tankers to and From Venezuela
item.description: The move is an escalation of military operations and a pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s leader. But its scope and economic impact are not clear.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Simon Romero, Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Oil tankers anchored in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. Venezuela relies entirely on tankers to export its oil to world markets.

item.title: Los ataques marítimos de EE. UU. en el Pacífico ponen a Colombia en alerta
item.description: Los recientes ataques del ejército estadounidense sugieren un cambio de enfoque geográfico tras las embestidas iniciales en el Caribe e intensifican las rencillas entre Bogotá y Washington.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:description: Las imágenes de video publicadas el lunes por el Comando Sur de Estados Unidos mostraban lo que, según el ejército estadounidense, eran ataques contra tres embarcaciones de narcotraficantes en el este del océano Pacífico.

item.title: Where Did Jeffrey Epstein Get His Money?
item.description: For years, rumors swirled about where Jeffrey Epstein’s wealth came from. A Times investigation reveals the truth of how a college dropout clawed his way to the pinnacle of American finance and society.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg, David Enrich, Claire Hogan, John Pappas, Stephanie Swart and Zach Caldwell

item.title: Widow of Officer Slain in Park Ave. Attack Sues Landlord Over Security
item.description: Didarul Islam and three others were killed when a gunman came to a Midtown skyscraper. The suit says the building had few physical barriers and lax surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The suit says the killer walked through the courtyard unimpeded and undetected, then opened fire.

item.title: Team Races Against Time to Save a Tangled Sea Lion in British Columbia
item.description: Experts tracked the sea lion, which had a rope around its neck, for over a month before they were able to catch up to it in Cowichan Bay, Canada.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.category: Vancouver Aquarium Marine Mammal Rescue Society

item.title: Penguins Become Prey for the Pumas of Patagonia
item.description: In Argentina, the return of pumas brought top predators back to the landscape — much to penguins’ dismay.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: When the Bones Were Good, These Bees Buried Their Babies
item.description: A cave in the Dominican Republic concealed thousands of years worth of animal bones that had been turned into nests by prehistoric bees.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: Judge Says He Will Not Immediately Halt Trump’s Ballroom Project
item.description: A federal judge said he would order the Trump administration to submit plans for the building by the end of the month, but allowed minor construction to continue for now.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Construction equipment for the new ballroom at the White House in November. President Trump’s vision for the project has steadily grown in scale from more modest proposals discussed in October.

item.title: Trump Expands Travel Ban and Restrictions to 20 More Countries
item.description: People from Syria, South Sudan and those with documents issued by the Palestinian Authority are included in the latest restrictions. More than 35 countries are now under U.S. travel restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Beyond the travel restrictions, the ban could have major ramifications for nationals of those countries already in the United States.

item.title: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners Pulls Out of Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Affinity Partners, Mr. Kushner’s private equity firm, played a small financial role in Paramount’s $108 billion offer, but it had attracted political attention to the deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, founded his investment firm, Affinity Partners, shortly after the end of Mr. Trump’s first term.

item.title: Does Discrimination Explain the Rightward Shift of Young Men?
item.description: Does discrimination drive alienation?
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

item.title: ‘Tartuffe’ Review: Matthew Broderick and David Cross Face Off
item.description: Matthew Broderick plays Tartuffe and David Cross his naïve prey in this Lucas Hnath adaptation of a 17th-century French comedy classic.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

media:content.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Matthew Broderick, left, as the title character and David Cross as Orgon in “Tartuffe” at New York Theater Workshop.

item.title: Mayor Adams’s Farewell To-Do List: Praise Himself, Undermine Mamdani
item.description: Before jetting off to Mexico, Mayor Eric Adams held an unusual news conference that included a time capsule, a new theme song and a defense of his one-term tenure.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:credit: Michael Loccisano/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Mayor Eric Adams is leaving for Mexico, his fourth international trip in the last three months.

item.title: Reiners’ Son to Be Charged With Murder
item.description: Also, the unemployment rate rose. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.

item.title: Lawmakers Demand the Release of Classified Boat Strike Video
item.description: Following classified hearings for all the members of the House and Senate, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth declined on Tuesday to release the unedited video of a boat attack in September that included a second strike to kill survivors.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth briefed lawmakers on Tuesday on the military’s strikes on boats in international waters.

item.title: Research Flights Over the Atlantic Could Help Improve Atmospheric River Forecasting
item.description: A global effort to better understand moisture-laden rivers in the sky, like those currently battering the West Coast, will take flight in January.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler

media:content.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A view out the window of a research mission by NOAA into atmospheric rivers over the Pacific in 2023.

item.title: Australia Can’t Recover From This
item.description: The victims were let down by a government whose role it is to do what individuals cannot: keep our nation safe from terrorism and mass shootings.
item.dc:creator: Alex Ryvchin

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Chicken Stroganoff
item.description: This Brazilian stroganoff is a riff on the classic Russian-American beef, mushroom and sour cream stew that was considered peak haute cuisine in the United States during the 1950s.
item.dc:creator: Nyt Cooking

media:content.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: Remixing Trump’s Economy Speech, Vance Strikes a Different Tone
item.description: Vice President JD Vance pleaded with everybody to just hang in there a little longer, saying the economy would improve.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh

media:content.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Vice President JD Vance, on Tuesday in Allentown, Pa., said of the economy, “I know that there is so much more progress to be made.”

item.title: How to Do a Little More Good in the World

item.title: Officials Release Enhanced Video of Possible Shooting Suspect at Brown
item.description: The Providence Police Department in Providence, R.I., released enhanced security-camera footage of a suspect in the Brown University shooting walking through the neighborhood hours before the tragedy took place.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

item.title: GiveWell’s Lightbulb Moment
item.description: Elie Hassenfeld was inspired to start GiveWell when he couldn’t find answers to his questions about charitable donations. He shares the organization’s origin story on “The Ezra Klein Show.”

item.description: The White House has never had a more loathsome occupant.

item.title: Nick Reiner Formally Charged With Murdering His Parents
item.description: Prosecutors said that Mr. Reiner killed his parents, Rob and Michelle Reiner, using a knife. He has not yet entered a plea.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Jill Cowan

media:content.media:credit: Aude Guerrucci/Reuters
media:content.media:description: If convicted, Nick Reiner could be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole or the death penalty.

item.title: Two More Heritage Foundation Trustees Resign Over Support for Tucker Carlson
item.description: Three trustees have left since the think tank’s president backed the conservative podcaster’s friendly interview with Nick Fuentes.

media:content.media:description: The Washington offices of the Heritage Foundation.

item.title: India Charges Pakistan-Based Groups in April Terrorist Attack in Kashmir
item.description: India claims that Pakistan sponsored the terrorists responsible for killing 26 people in the disputed region, an accusation Pakistan denies.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar

media:content.media:credit: Reuters
media:content.media:description: People mourn one of the victims killed in an attack in Pahalgam, Indian-administered part of Kashmir, in April.

item.title: At Many Top Law Schools, Black Student Enrollment Continues to Drop
item.description: The New York Times examined data from 18 of the nation’s top law schools and found that first-year Black enrollment had increased at only four, including at Harvard.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul

media:content.media:credit: Billy Hickey for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Harvard Law School in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: ISIS and the Bondi Beach Attack
item.description: Australian officials say the suspects were motivated by ISIS. It suggests the group may still have the ability to inspire acts of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial at Bondi Beach yesterday.
